Playbook to (actually) succeeding in crypto long term:

1. Develop an edge (easiest ones are info/speed/patience/risk management or a mix of multiple - for those with time, info/speed are best imo)

2. Make a series of high-conviction, yet diligently weighted bets across multiple time frames

3. Religiously take profits into stables/BTC

4. Use said profits to reinvest into either your business (which generates cash flow), or cash flow generating assets

Thought I'd give my thoughts on "escaping the rat race" without quitting your job..

1. Your #1 goal is skill acquisition (right now the most asymmetric upside is in AI/crypto/digital products imo). Focus on building skills, not making money. The money comes as a result of getting really good at something.

2. Weekends are your best friend - don't quit your day job, as it's hard to build a proper business from a position of defence. Utilise gaps in your time (i.e. weekends and time after/before work to chip away at point #1).

3. Pick your sacrifice - more time focusing on skill acquisition/business naturally detracts from other areas like friends/family/hobbies. Balance is ultimately important, but something has to give if you're serious about "escaping" - at least in the short term.

4. Be realistic: Escaping the "rat race" is more likely to come from consistently stacking smaller wins/compounding wealth over time, as opposed to hitting a huge trade or business idea. Time is both your biggest enemy and best friend here.

On the Sunday before the beginning of each month (today), I do a massive planning day.

It‚Äôs the highest leverage thing you can do.

‚Ä¢ Update 2nd brain on Notion
‚Ä¢ Reflect on monthly achievements and goals for next month
‚Ä¢ Update all my AI chats so memory is up to date + create monthly summaries
‚Ä¢ Talk to key team members and establish clear objectives
‚Ä¢ Review all financials and make tweaks where necessary

It‚Äôs so easy to get caught up in the day-to-day (especially as a content creator, as there is always unlimited content to create).

But you NEED to schedule pure planning/organizational days so you remain on the right track.

If you want to ‚Äúsucceed‚Äù in business/life, the most important prerequisite is to truly understand yourself.

Your strengths, your weaknesses, your flaws.

Self-introspection is the only way to break past your limits.

I have realised many of my weaknesses are actually super powers, and vice versa.

i.e. my impulsivity & obsessiveness. Powerful tools when harnessed, but these traits can also break you if you let them take control.

You need to structure your life to allow your strengths to thrive, whilst minimising the negative impacts of your weaknesses. I‚Äôm still working on doing this, but I feel like I‚Äôve made great progress over the past year.

Obviously seeing a psychologist to assist with this stuff is greatly beneficial (even if you don‚Äôt have a ‚Äúproblem‚Äù). But if you‚Äôre shy, or just want to kick off the process in a frictionless way - brain dumping into ChatGPT and getting some feedback can actually be quite insightful/therapeutic. Remember, the more information you feed it - the more capable it is. But I still recommend reflecting with an actual human in tandem.

Getting rich, achieving ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù - whatever that is to you, is more of a reflection of how you‚Äôre able to maneuver your own psychology, as opposed to get-rich gimmicks. Knowledge is power, but only if you know how to apply it effectively to your own life.

5. Opportunity cost

One of the most powerful ways to reassess your portfolio is by asking:

If this position were magically converted to fiat overnight - would I buy it back at the current price?

If not, why are you still holding it?

This mental reset strips away attachment and forces clarity on capital efficiency.

Further examples:

‚Ä¢ Parking capital in stagnant assets with no volatility or catalysts incurs hidden costs (that liquidity could be rotated into higher-conviction, higher-upside setups).

‚Ä¢ Holding drawdowns (sunk cost fallacy) a double loss - you‚Äôre bleeding time and sidelining capital that could be compounding elsewhere with momentum and narrative alignment.

It's equally (if not more) important to look at where you're NOT allocated, vs where you are currently allocated.

4. First principles thinking

This is essentially a method of problem-solving that involves breaking down complex issues into their most basic and fundamental parts.

When investing long-term, ask yourself if the root fundamentals make sense (instead of chasing narratives/buzzwords).

 ‚Ä¢ What problem does it solve?
 ‚Ä¢ Is the token necessary?
 ‚Ä¢ Are the incentives sustainable?

3. Asymmetric risk/reward

Limit downside, and let the upside take care of itself.

The best plays are those where you don't lose much when you're wrong, but win big when you‚Äôre right.

A simple way of implementing this is by enforcing max drawdown/invalidation parameters, evaluating R/R on your trades. Know exactly where your idea breaks (price, time, or narrative).

Most of the top traders I know are extremely quick to cut a bad position, and don't let their ego get in the way of doing so.

2. Compounding wins

You don‚Äôt need to catch every market move.

You just need to stack small, repeatable wins and avoid blowups.

Most people chase 10x trades and end up back at zero.

The best traders I know (like @gametheorizing) are extremely disciplined, and focus on compounding wealth over time via a series of smaller bets.

Success in crypto is ultimately a function of survival.

Focus on staying in the game long enough to let compounding do the heavy lifting.

Portfolio strategy that has worked well for many of my friends in the space: Sit 100% in stables, and take individual bets when opportunities arise.

Essentially, treating stables as your default position, and any altcoin trade as a deviation away from that position.

It's not the right strategy for everyone, and you do need skill to manage the entries/exits of your active positions - but i've seen it work many times.

Pros:
‚Ä¢ No downside risk (minus inflation/opportunity cost)
‚Ä¢ Liquidity to take advantage of big drawdowns whilst others panic
‚Ä¢ Less emotion
‚Ä¢ Leverage to go big when the stars align on a trade

Cons:
‚Ä¢ Rules out long-term fundamental investing (where I have historically done well, alongside many others)
‚Ä¢ Requires a higher degree of skill with your active trades
‚Ä¢ Opportunity cost/risk of being caught off-side (slightly mitigated by the fact that in an uptrend, you're likely trading bullish continuation anyway)

Currently, I am doing a 50/50 split. 50% long term, 50% stables (this strategy). That's where I am most comfortable, and what aligns the best with my temperament. The best strategy is the one which aligns with your own skills/pitfalls.

Just make sure before you enter a coin, you've clearly defined where it sits in your overall portfolio strategy.

This is mine.

The 50/50 split I use for my crypto portfolio at this stage in the cycle:

50% in long-term investments: Think $BTC, $ETH, $SOL, $HYPE etc. Will still look to TP a decent % on these as prices head into mania territory, but with the idea of being exposed longer term (multi-year).

50% in short-mid term swing investments: Mainly altcoins that are narratively aligned with the market, and are exhibiting relative strength, + some low-cap punts that could pay off in the right environment. I'm much more "ruthless" with this section of my portfolio (i.e., cutting on weakness, tweaking portfolio based on opportunity cost), as I'm under no illusions that most of these coins will go to 0 and never come back. That's my base case at least, if I'm proven wrong - great. Sometimes I'm heavier in cash with this portion of my portfolio, sometimes I'm more heavily invested - it depends on where we are in the cycle.

Bonus: You can also have "sub weightings" for a position. Take BTC for example: You could have 50% that you hold long term, and 50% in your short-term to mid-term portfolio that you swing trade based on strength. The key is making this dissection very clear in your portfolio - I recommend using separate wallets/coin trackers for both: tagged "short term" and "long term".

Most people f*ck up because they mix and mash all their holdings in one, without a clear plan for each holding.

(excluding stablecoin weighting - which oscillates between 30-50% depending on if I have active trades open)

The implications are still fresh, and as more information comes out, we will likely get more clarity.

Yet, despite the clear longer-term bullish implications, the AI crypto market is still experiencing short-term downside, following NVIDIA's lead.

I think this dip is creating great opportunities to scoop up quality projects at discounts.

The good thing about AI in crypto, and the reason I think it actually BENEFITS from new launches like R-1, is because it can leverage ALL models, with better models accelerating the development of high-quality agents and agentic enterprises.
DeepSeek specifically will also shift value accrual from the compute layer to the agents built on top by reducing computational costs.

AI agents are a very powerful onboarding tool for Web3, as they simplify an otherwise complex user experience.

As these agents harness better models, the end result will be even smoother and more functional use cases.

There is another major beneficiary of this: AI crypto.

Despite also falling victim to the broader market selloff, decentralised AI protocols clearly stand to benefit.

Lower costs = more scalable and profitable business models.

But, ultimately, I think it's great for the consumer.

Lower cost AI models democratise access to AI technology by making it cheaper to consume.
The DeepSeek story/reaction is a fascinating one, as it highlights how critical the battle for AI dominance will be in terms of winning the global one.

Risk assets like crypto also sold off in anticipation of a weak US open, with the sell-off being compounded by the looming FOMC interest rate decision in 2 days, which was already resulting in some de-risking.

And because NVIDIA has been such a strong gainer and contributed to the majority of the Nasdaq index's recent rise, it makes sense that the sell-off is equally reflexive to the downside when it retraces.

Well, if DeepSeek was able to develop BETTER AI with WEAKER chips, then this fundamentally affects NVIDIA's business model.

Energy-intensive models require better hardware, where NVIDIA is the market leader.

But if the trend moves towards more energy-efficient models, this could impact NVIDIA's bottom line.

But even though there are still question marks, one thing is for sure: It has spooked US investors.

$NVIDIA shares plummeted -21% for the day, and over a trillion dollars was wiped off US tech stock valuations.

But why?
Elon Musk has also weighed in on the debate, noting that DeepSeek "obviously" has about 50,000 Nvidia H100 chips that can't be mentioned due to US export controls.

But, there has been some skepticism as to the legitimacy of these claims.

Was it really developed in under 2 months? Is it really as energy efficient as they claim?

We don't know for sure, and the skepticism is justified.
To add fuel to the fire, DeepSeek just released another open-source AI model, Janus-Pro-7B, which currently outperforms OpenAI's DALL-E 3 across multiple benchmarks.

And, it's reportedly 93% less energy intensive than ChatGPT's o1 model.

Making it the most efficient AI LLM model on the planet.
But, the mind-blowing part is that despite the small budget and short development time, it actually outperforms OpenAI's ChatGPT across a variety of benchmarks.
Post-launch, it quickly flipped ChatGPT to become the number one app in the App Store in both the US and China.
This is compared to the hundreds of millions or billions of dollars US companies spend on their AI technologies, which often take years to develop.

To be a successful trader/investor, it's critical that you understand your limits, and what's sustainable for you.

If you work a 9-to-5 job, intra-day scalping isn't sustainable; it's better to pick an H4 or D1 strategy for your entries.

If you're a fundamental investor, it's best to focus on long-term trends and position during quiet periods, as opposed to hopping on every new hot rotation.

The key to succeeding in markets is staying in the game. And for that, you need a sustainable strategy.

It's the same with the gym. If you want a good physique, but you're time limited, it's better to be consistent with a 3-day/week split than inconsistent with a bro split.

Consistency trumps all.

6. @0xfluid - $FLUID

Fluid captures stablecoin growth by optimizing their use in lending and liquidity aggregation.

It consolidates liquidity across DeFi ‚Äúmoney legos‚Äù into a unified layer, offering high-yield lending opportunities for stablecoins like USDC & USDT, thus attracting more stablecoin inflows.

5. @pendle_fi - $PENDLE

Pendle captures stablecoin growth by creating a yield market that directly integrates stablecoins and their derivatives.

It splits yield-bearing assets into Principal Tokens (PT) and Yield Tokens (YT).

This lets users speculate on or hedge against stablecoin yields, which are a massive driver of DeFi activity.

4. @CurveFinance - $CRV

CRV is the home of stablecoin liquidity.

It also has its own native over-collateralised stablecoin, $crvUSD.

CRV (specifically veCRV lockers) earn trading fees from their liquidity pools.

If stablecoin trading volume grows, so do CRV rewards.

3. @aave - $AAVE

Aave is a money market where users borrow and lend assets (stables are the most borrowed).

They recently launched their own over-collateralised stable, $GHO.

AAVE holders benefit as stablecoin demand drives lending fees. GHO‚Äôs interest payments funnel to Aave DAO.

Basically, AAVE is a proxy bet on stablecoin lending demand.

2. MakerDAO - $MKR

They're the issuer of $DAI, the original decentralised stablecoin.

MKR holders gain from DAI's growth through stability fees. More DAI demand can trigger MKR buybacks and burns.

As USDe‚Äôs circulating supply grows, the protocol‚Äôs revenue scales accordingly.

They are also launching their own blockchain in collaboration with Securitize, and are focused on the continued expansion of USDe.

In terms of altcoin bets, $ENA is one of the most obvious stablecoin proxies.

1. @ethena_labs - $ENA

Ethena's stablecoin, USDe, accounts for 2.3% of the total stablecoin market.

They generate revenue via a unique mechanism of backing USDe, a synthetic dollar, with delta-hedged positions on staked Ethereum (e.g., stETH) and short perpetual futures contracts.

2. Major L1s (Ethereum, Solana & Tron).

This is another broad one.

But if stablecoin volumes continue to grow, the L1s with the most adoption benefit through increased fee generation.

$ETH is currently the home of RWA, and $SOL is the home of speculative trading. Tron is the most dominant chain for $USDT supply, often holding over 50%.
So although it's not a direct proxy, Coinbase does benefit from the growth of stablecoins, USDC specifically.

They also have rewards programs for holding USDC on the platform, which incentivises users to keep USDC on the exchange, increasing overall engagement and transaction activity, which can indirectly boost revenue through fees.

1. @coinbase ( $COIN )

Coinbase has a partnership with Circle, the issuer of $USDC.

The interest earned on USDC reserves is shared between Coinbase and Circle.

Thus, Coinbase makes money from the growth of USDC.

I'll write a tutorial thread once its live.

Tip #1: Use the same chat and create a project within ChatGPT (this will allow GPT to remember and reference your previous inputs).

Tip #2: Once you have a backlog of inputs in the same project/chat, ask ChatGPT to analyse the chat for areas that you struggle with. This will help you improve over time.

Tip #3: Ask GPT to give you a "homework plan" (you can even ask for specific videos, articles, etc. for further reference).

Tip #4: In this guide, I provided some basic tools to test, but feel free to add your own indicators and trading system to create your own master prompts. I'll cover this in future threads.
Now that you have the 4-step process and some prompts to test, let's review some bonus tips to improve your TA learning with AI.

To put the final touches on basic TA, we can utilise a volume profile.

Like the Stoch RSI, this is not a primary price action tool.

Instead, it's a tool to use for additional confluence.

This tool helps you analyse overbought/oversold scenarios.

It's great in conjunction with S/R levels and a momentum indicator

The key to this prompt is asking o3 if the Stoch RSI confirms or denies what we see on the S/R and 200D MA levels (as those are our main price action tools).

I recommend testing these prompts independently to get the complete answers to each prompt. https://t.co/v2jGcbvbVZ

Gemini also has excellent video capabilities.

You can get it to analyse YouTube videos, podcasts, and live streams, which can be a huge time-saver.

I've been really impressed by Gemini recently, and I arguably use it more than GPT for specific tasks.

If you're already using Gmail and Google Calendar, it's a no-brainer to integrate them into your daily workflow.

In terms of task management, it's even better than GPT for this reason.

It's a fantastic LLM for summarizing Google meetings/Gmail, setting reminders, or generating ideas for Google presentations via Docs/Slides.

Gemini's models are among the fastest AI models, so their outputs are almost instant and significantly faster than those of ChatGPT, Grok, and Claude.

4. Gemini: Google-related tasks/deep research/video

Much like Grok is the AI assistant for X, Gemini is my go-to assistant for Google-related needs.

If you use the web via Google Chrome, Gemini is already integrated into your browser, making it a very convenient AI model.

It's also very good at creative writing.

Personally, I tend to use GPT more for writing, but I have heard good things from others, so it's worth testing out and seeing which model you prefer.

While I don't necessarily utilise Claude's coding abilities on a regular basis, its coding skills make it the perfect model for dealing with numbers.

Some real-world use cases:

‚Ä¢ Analysing spreadsheet data
‚Ä¢ Analysing images with data involved
‚Ä¢ Explain/creating finance plans (Perpexity is slightly better at this IMO, which I'll break down later)
‚Ä¢ Tutoring for kids

3. Claude: Math/coding/writing

Claude's most recent 3.7 model has seen a significant increase in its ability to solve mathematical tasks.

Making it the perfect AI for math/coding-related tasks. https://t.co/L7MWlXdoPJ

In a research capacity, Grok is super fast and is my go-to for anything news-based or time-sensitive.

I'm not personally into it, but for NSFW stuff, it also takes the cake. üòÇ

Some examples to play around with:

‚Ä¢ Important news & events over the last 24H
‚Ä¢ Finding trending topics on X
‚Ä¢ Sourcing tweets
‚Ä¢ Sentiment analysis (i.e., what are people saying about ___ )
‚Ä¢ Drafting tweet ideas & replies

2. Grok: Real-time research & news

Grok is a unique LLM because of its real-time X integration.

This feature essentially makes Grok an immediate assistant that can scan all of Twitter in just a matter of seconds.

Grok is best for prompts/topics that require the latest data.

ChatGPT is multi-purpose, so it's great for a lot of stuff - even math and coding (but there are better picks for these niches, which I'll get into later).

Another thing that GPT is really good at is image-gen. It's my go to for basic graphics.

1. ChatGPT: Advice/organisation/photo-gen

I treat GPT as my multi-purpose AI assistant.

One of the biggest changes I made in 2025 was having an iPad dedicated to ChatGPT at my desk.

Throughout my workday, I can braindump into ChatGPT and have my train of thought clearly organised.

"Why is sentiment so bad when $BTC is above $100k?!"

1. Most people hold alts, and the majority (with the exception of AI/some utility/RWA) have underperformed BTC.

2. The constant "alt season" fakeouts are increasing skepticism, and the longer this goes on the less people believe (time vs price based capitulation).

3. There are so many rotations, and unless you're spending hours per day in the space it's almost impossible to keep up with (nor should you feel obligated to - but FOMO is a killer in this industry).

4. Post-inauguration there's no "North Star" for participants to cling onto (this could change at any moment, of course). FOMC is also in 6 days which will shake things up again (for better or worse).

5. (This one is a bit more outlandish - but interesting to consider): I think the rapid development of AI has introduce a time-based FOMO we've never seen before (due to how it will radicalise the labour industry) - and people have a right to be concerned (I think about it almost daily). Time pressure leads to more reliance on external sources (i.e. crypto) to "make it" - and the longer people don't "make it", the more anxiety builds.

There are other reasons too (lack of clear macro direction, reliance on the 4-year cycle theory etc.) but I think these are some of the main ones.

The good news is, there is still a ridiculous amount of opportunity in this market and as we know, things can turn at any moment (look at the last 2 weeks - we've been oscillating from despair to excitement weekly on this app), and a few days of positive price action seems to wipe the memories of most. Just have to stay in the game (do whatever you need to not to get shaken out - even if it means stepping away for a bit).

The reason why the "cycle top is in/we're late" discussion is so polarising, is because the market falls into 2 camps:

A) Those who have already made a significant amount of money are naturally going to shift into preservation mode (wind down phase)

B) Those who haven't achieved their goals yet and are searching for opportunity (wind up phase)

Both camps are operating on very different time frames, and their thinking is biased towards their objective (to preserve vs create wealth).

The person who chases two rabbits catches neither.

This saying rings especially true for crypto.

To develop a real edge, you need to go DEEP and become an expert at ONE thing.

It could be LTF trading, news trading, fundamental analysis into AI, DeFi, content creation, working for a project etc.

Just pick one thing and stick to it.

If I'm investing in a high-conviction altcoin long-term, I like to split my holdings into 2 parts:

1. Long-term bag (I won't trade it, only take profit)
2. Active trading bag (I'll use high-time-frame invalidations/key levels on the chart to enter and exit)

The latter requires more attention, but this way I benefit from the upside of my long-term thesis without full exposure to the downside.

The percentage you assign to each depends on your conviction.

It could be 80/20 for something you're very bullish on.

Or 20/80 for more of a "long-shot" play.

Just ensure you define your exact strategy before making a purchase.

Well, it's not an exact science - but there are some signals we can use to spot a squeeze before it happens.

Let me break them down.

‚Ä¢ Deeply negative funding rates: An excess of shorts in the market sets ideal conditions
‚Ä¢ Sudden spikes in open interest and volume: Signifies traders positioning themselves ahead of the move
‚Ä¢ Low-liquidity altcoins: These are easier to manipulate and more volatile during squeezes

Coins under these parameters can move explosively to the upside at any time, especially in sectors that were heavily beaten down, like memes and AI.

That's why the biggest moves in the last few days have been on coins with CEX perp listings, which have been heavily shorted.

But how can you work out which ones are next?

‚Ä¢ Initial price move forces liquidations
‚Ä¢ Liquidations add buying pressure, pushing prices even higher
‚Ä¢ People speculate on further upside, resulting in increased long interest

Why is this happening?

Many alts have been heavily shorted, as funding rates ticked extremely negative across the market.

However, when prices begin to move higher, as we've been seeing, short sellers are forced to close their positions.

This triggers a wave of liquidations, creating a self-reinforcing price surge.

A week ago, I highlighted that we'll likely see many short squeezes across the market.

Since then, we've started to see alts pull some crazy moves.

Short squeeze season is here.

Over the next two weeks, expect some violent altcoin rallies as shorts get wiped out.

In my opinion, the 2 sectors with the best risk/reward over the coming months are AI & RWA. Theses below:

AI: Has the benefit of constantly-accelerating tech progression/corresponding news flow. Agents still only ~$13b compared to memes at $111b (still $50b excluding $DOGE & $TRUMP). 

Seems like an obvious trade, relatively undervalued vs the mindshare it commands, which I like as a mid-term setup. Also perfect blend of left/right curve as it's a strong retail narrative, but also has fundamental drivers + the interest of serious players/funds.

RWA: Seems like the clear beneficiary of new crypto regulation. Sentiment is also equally as important here. Many companies were unwilling/afraid to take risks and tokenise assets due to regulatory red tape/SEC scrutiny. With the new administration, this sentiment completely shifts and imo there will be a "race" to be first-to-market and capitalise (as the opportunity is huge for first movers).

Lots of high upside opportunities within the sector as $OM & $ONDO command big valuations - but the rest of the market hasn't fully woken up yet (on a relative basis). Also, there are less coins than AI/memes, which makes it easier for sector leaders to run (and easier to position). It's also harder to launch a legitimate RWA project as you need proper licensing/deal pipeline. Much easier to spin up an agent/meme. Makes the "set and forget" method much easier which I like (and I also think many market participants respond to).

In society "failure" is often viewed as something to be avoided, but it's often the catalyst for real growth and personal development.

You can't have success without failure.

Just like life and death, day and night, happiness and sadness - they go hand in hand.

My mindset of failure has changed a lot over the past year or so.

Even recently (in the past 2 months) I took 2 fairly big losses in the context of my net worth - but instead of feeling sorry for myself I try and look at the bigger picture and what I can learn for next time.

All my biggest lessons have come during my greatest losses.

I'd argue that taking a big loss every now and then is essential to eradicate complacency and keep you on your toes. 

Success isn't linear - your job is to use the troughs to compound into bigger peaks.

The key to winning in crypto is AWARENESS.

You don't need a complex system.

Just be aware of what's happening and react accordingly.

Keep your long term portfolio simple, especially if you're trading.

Ideally 5-10 coins max.

It will take less time to manage, and free up your mind to take advantage of other trading opportunities.

The best coins to trade short-term, are ironically the coins you hold long-term.

Why?

If you have long-term conviction in a project, chances are you're regularly keeping up to date with fundamental changes + price action.

Pattern recognition in trading is very important.

And this can only be built over time (by witnessing how price responds to certain events).

Many of my best short-term trades are also coins I hold in my long-term spot portfolio.

There is no shame in waiting for the market to go risk-on again, then start building new positions on confirmation of an uptrend.

CT glorifies bottom-pickers, but the reality is most people end up catching knives.

You need to know when to be defensive, and when to be offensive.

4 things you can do in a "boring" market to still make money.

1. DeFi (there are lots of incentives right now, for example on Sonic).

2. Learn to trade (or at least learn the basics), it's never to late to up-skill.

3. Consolidate your portfolio into high conviction assets/research new protocols.

4. Pair trading. It's particularly effective if you want to maintain delta neutrality but you have a bias regarding a specific coin. More people should take advantage of this approach imo.

"What do I do if I'm holding a coin I'm no longer bullish on, but it's already dropped -70%."

I think this is a position MANY people are in right now.

You basically have 3 options.

1. Consolidate into better assets you believe in more
2. Swap for stables on bounces (and maybe a % now)
3. Swap for a superior relative strength asset (that will likely bounce harder during the next rally)

Which one should you choose?

1. Is the simplest if you want to maintain the same net market exposure
2. Is good if you really need stables and it's the difference between surviving this cycle or not
3. Is for more experienced traders, but can speed up your recovery if executed correctly.

Of course you can also combine a mix of all three.

One RWA vertical I've always been bullish on conceptually, yet haven't seen anyone properly nail yet, is real estate.

We've seen strong PMF across T-bills, stablecoins, but not yet property - which IMO is one of the asset classes that benefits most (due to fractionalisation of an asset class with an increasing barrier to entry for the average person).

In the future, the ability to leverage against these tokenised positions (either on chain, or with banks/neo banks would be game changing - there are already private brokers who do it, but more alternatives could catalyse adoption).

In terms of exposure, I recently invested in the @estatexeu seed - it's one to keep an eye on with TGE tomorrow. The whole platform is built around a) providing opportunities for investors to buy tokenised property, and b) providing a scalable solution for anyone (funds, retail) to tokenise their own real estate. Brock Pierce, the co-founder of Tether, is a backer. As with all new launches, I recommend assessing the valuation on launch.

It makes sense that treasuries were the first RWA to take off, as it's simple and there are less variables. But now we have better tech + proof of demand, I think more complex RWAs (like real estate) will begin to develop.

The asset is great, and it perhaps has the greatest tokenomics in crypto for an altcoin, but my point is - fundamental assessment must be seperate from price assessment.

The higher in price a quality asset goes, assuming fundamentals remain constant, the worse a buy it becomes.

i.e. $HYPE was a brilliant buy at $10, fantastic at $20, great at $30, good at $40, decent at $50 and so on..

There will come a point where it becomes a "bad" buy, despite being a good asset.

And the same in reverse. There are some absolute trash, scam, vapourware projects which, at the right price, represent brilliant buys.

If you're still struggling to implement AI in your daily life, this post is for you.

One of the biggest complaints about AI is that it's not "practical" to implement.

Here are some convenient (low-hanging fruit) ways to start using AI daily:

1. Replace your Google searches

Instead of digging through 10 tabs and scrolling web pages, just have AI find exactly what you need.

You'll learn a LOT about AI just by replacing Google with an AI-powered solution (like ChatGPT).

2. Use AI-powered Chrome extensions

There are many "AI assistant" Chrome extensions you can add to your daily workflow to increase productivity.

This is the fastest way to start working closely with AI on daily tasks (Docs, Slides, Gmail, browsing the web, etc.)

3. Voice notes dump

This is something I still do daily.

Open ChatGPT and do a complete brain dump (on any topic).

From there, you can ask for new ideas, blindspots in your ideology, and more.

This mimics having an actual conversation with an LLM.

4. Make AI your assistant

Gemini is probably the best model for this. You can start to manage your entire Google Workspace through Gemini.

Instead of looking for emails, docs, etc. just have AI source exactly what you need.

5. Start building/experimenting

This is the most complicated of the list, but it's also one of the highest leverage.

Some ideas here:

Use tools like Zapier and n8n to build automation flows.

Build custom GPTs.

Use Claude to build apps you need.

Using AI in your daily life is as complicated as you want it to be.

Bonus: Create content. This is one way to get an edge.

Obviously, access to network/deal flow/monetisation opportunities are big pluses, but even if you don't go "viral," the act of creating content itself makes you a lot smarter and helps with memory retention.

I attribute a large chunk of my crypto knowledge to the thousands of hours I've spent writing about it.

6. DEVELOP AN EDGE

Most investors in crypto blindly buy without a real edge.

I want you to think about what yours is.

‚Ä¢ Do you have an information edge?
‚Ä¢ Do you have a speed edge?
‚Ä¢ Do you have an emotional edge?
‚Ä¢ Do you have an execution edge?

If not, now is the time to build one.

Choose what you focus on based on what you enjoy doing and your temperament.

Then commit over the next few months to going deep.

5. IDENTIFY DISLOCATIONS

Dips create dislocations/asymmetries/opportunities, as prices decouple from the underlying fundamentals.

There are plenty of these in the market.

My recommendation is going deep into a niche (for example AI), and doing a deep dive of the sector.

In addition to the points mentioned earlier, compare products that have:

‚Ä¢ Revenue-generation
‚Ä¢ A strong moat
‚Ä¢ Strong runway
‚Ä¢ A strong team/backers.

Your job is to spot outliers before they normalize.
In terms of WHEN to accumulate these alts, I wrote a full guide which can be found here.

4. IDENTIFY THE NEXT BIG NARRATIVE(S)

Just as bull markets don't last forever, neither does the bear.

At some point, things will turn. And you want to make sure your watchlist is 100% prepared for when that time comes.

Monitor:

‚Ä¢ The narratives that are growing in mindshare (mindshare can stay detached from price until conditions turn)
‚Ä¢ The alts which are maintaining relative strength vs the rest of the market (these will likely pump the hardest once things reverse)
‚Ä¢ The projects who keep shipping throughout boring periods, you want to invest in the real builders, not the hype chasers
‚Ä¢ The projects which maintain a strong sense of community, even during boring periods
‚Ä¢ Metric growth (TVL, fees, users): If a project is actually GROWING during a downtrend, that is a very good sign you've spotted an outlier

Projects which tick all of the above criteria are well positioned to rebound the strongest.

3. EXPAND YOUR NETWORK

During quiet markets, it's actually easier to build a network.

1. Many figures in the industry who were previously inaccessible are now more accessible.

2. Only serious individuals are left, as all the tourists have been filtered out.

You can create a group with like-minded individuals who are willing to learn/build throughout this period with you.

Alternatively, you could join an existing community (like @mileshighclub_) and network within the group. The vibe is actually much better now than it was during peak-bull, as only the serious members are left - which raises the overall quality of information/discussion.
I also have a Trader's Hub in @mileshighclub_ which is dedicated to fast-tracking people to becoming profitable traders, even if you have no experience.

Difficult markets are arguably the best times to learn to trade, as you're battle-testing your system under extreme conditions.

When conditions improve, you'll comparatively find it easy.

There are amazing free resources online from the likes of @CryptoCred.

2. LEARN TO TRADE

Even if you're an investor, having an understanding of the general basics of technicals and price action is so important.

Even if you're not scalping, you need to be able to accurately define support/resistance, and execute TP/de-risk strategy to better manage your portfolio.

Technicals are great as they are black-and-white, which is good for more inexperienced participants who may not have the fundamental nous to make moves based on intuition.

I'll be doing a full thread on exactly how I'm using AI in my daily work flow soon, so make sure to follow me @milesdeutscher to stay in the loop.

It has been a big focus of mine over the past few months.

Here are some ideas to get started:

Bonus prompting tips:

‚Ä¢ Utilize @grok's "DeepSearch" & "Research" modes for limited data responses
‚Ä¢ Make sure the latest LLM is selected (Grok 3 right now)
‚Ä¢ Be direct with the format you want (bullet point, table, etc)
‚Ä¢ For complex topics, add "Explain like I'm 5."

Prompt #10: Team credibility

"How credible is the team behind ___ project?"

Continuing with $SOL, @grok broke down the key team members and their previous experience.

For lower caps, data may be limited, so make sure to ask follow-up questions. https://t.co/u3QurOX6zx

Prompt #9: Volume

"Over the past week, what projects are seeing the most volume in the ___ sector in the___ market cap range?"

@grok can easily aggregate volume data across various narratives and market cap ranges.

I quickly searched for noteworthy memes in the 100M range. https://t.co/3rIoUZ9uez

Prompt #8: Pros & Cons

"What are the Pros and Cons of ___ project right now?"

While getting the bullish catalysts is great, AI is fantastic for outlining potential cons you might be missing.

This is an excellent prompt for quickly analyzing the R:R on any given altcoin trade. https://t.co/jWMHzVygDG

Prompt #7: Top Tweets

"What are the top tweets saying about ___ project over the past two weeks?"

Like prompt #7, this is an excellent "overview" style prompt for analysing the top tweets about any altcoin in real-time. https://t.co/nkVUSTuwJl

Prompt #6: Upcoming Catalysts

"What are the most recent bullish catalysts for ___ project."

This prompt is excellent for summarising "why" you should buy an altcoin.

You can also ask it to create a SWOT analysis so you can understand the weaknesses/threats as well. https://t.co/i1Bi5YdWZd

Prompt #5: Seed round investments

This is one of my favourite prompts.

"Give me the seed round investments for ___ project."

Sometimes data be limited here, but @grok will point you in the right direction and explain any gaps in its output. https://t.co/OZfqYG7p4w

Prompt #4: Social Sentiment

"What is the social sentiment around ___ right now?"

Much like prompt 1, we can utilize Grok to track sentiment on CT (not just social metrics) around a specific project.

Again, I used $SOL for this example, but you can use this for any altcoin. https://t.co/w2atb9y1rq

Prompt #3: Macro

"Source the top resources discussing macroeconomics and crypto."

Grok will even cite the original source, making it easy to scan top macro/crypto events.

If you're a content creator or writer, this is a game-changer. https://t.co/5Cyp18GeYw

Prompt #2: Unlock Schedule

"Give me ___ projects' recent token unlocks."

For this example, I used $SOL.

If you want to source upcoming unlocks, @grok will provide a step-by-step guide on where to find the most accurate data. This is one of its best features. https://t.co/6kdgQF7EdW

Prompt #1: Social Engagement

"Give me top coins by social metrics over the past 7D".

@grok will scan all accounts posting about social metrics across tokens and give you a simple bullet-point list.

This is a crucial prompt as social engagement and token price are heavily correlated.

Even for long-term positions, I always use technicals to invalidate if needed.

Conviction doesn‚Äôt mean ignoring invalidation levels. If a key level breaks, I cut a percentage. If it reclaims, I reassess.

Every buy must have a clear invalidation. No catching knives. No blindly holding just because it‚Äôs a ‚Äúlong-term play.‚Äù

The key difference is differentiating whether a trade is short-term vs. long-term.

For short-term trades, I have a plan to go 100% in and out.

For long-term positions I never *fully* exit, I trim based on conviction:

‚Ä¢ High conviction: Invalidate 30%
‚Ä¢ Mid conviction: 40‚Äì50%
‚Ä¢ Lower conviction: 60%

Risk management isn‚Äôt about selling everything. It‚Äôs about knowing when to reduce exposure and when to go risk on.

Before you start optimizing with AI: Get the basics right first.

An organized to-do list is the #1 highest-leverage thing you can do in life (aside from getting good sleep).

An organized mind is a healthy mind.

So many knock-on effects:
- Compounding effect of ‚Äúgetting stuff done‚Äù consistently over time is massive
- Less stress (keeping everything in your head takes its toll)
- Allows you to objectively review & tweak your output

I recommend Notion because they have in-built AI, and you can tweak it with Zapier + your LLM of choice later on.

4. KNOWLEDGE

This is your opportunity to add additional context.

The more information you provide, the more accurate the response will be.

Most people mess up because their prompts are shallow.

Go deep and put it all on the table.

3. CONSTRAINTS

This is where you add any limitations, whether financial/time-based/or preferences.

E.g., if you're asking for the best fiction novel but don't like romance, this is the step where you tell it.

2. OUTPUT

This is how you specify how you'd like the AI to format its response.

This is important, as some responses can be too long or formatted convolutedly.

You can even ask for a simple table to save/screenshot.

AI will still be the biggest narrative of 2025, BUT - make sure to focus on projects that:

‚Ä¢ Are first movers/leaders (you want your AI holdings to be price responsive to the narrative)
‚Ä¢ Have a strong USP
‚Ä¢ Have found product-market fit
‚Ä¢ Have a strong moat
‚Ä¢ Have REAL user growth/traction

TLDR: Find the real products in a sea of larps.

An over-looked aspect of narrative trading is identifying the REAL proxies of a narrative.

If a token you're holding is *supposed* to help you capture upside to a sector, but is underperforming - then it's probably the wrong token to hold.

For example, if you're trying to get exposure to the upside of AI, it's not as simple as longing any AI coin.

In March 2024, $RNDR & $FET were great AI proxies - now they're not.

Then it was $TAO - now it isn't.

Currently, the leading AI agent plays are the most reactive to AI hype.

What's price responsive changes over time.

You have to remain adaptive or you'll end up holding under-performers.

This isn't a recommendation to "chase" the latest hot coin, but a reminder to be mindful of whether your "proxy" is ACTUALLY a "proxy".

The most frustrating part is that the fundamentals are literally the best they've ever been in terms of facilitating adoption.

But the trade off is how it's opened Pandora's box for blatant scamming.

And I'm not talking about price.

There are still amazing use cases I'm bullish on. 

I'm referencing how it used to feel like a proper community of people supporting each other. 

Now it's just full barbarian/outsiders coming in just to rob people.

I feel a bit sick about the state of the industry right now. 

Honestly sad.

The timeline is f*cking insane right now. 

Never seen anything like it. 

Worse than FTX.

It's been an extremely frustrating cycle for anyone who's genuinely passionate about the industry and its technology (myself included).

There are so many game-changing use cases for the blockchain (payments, tokenisation, AI, gaming etc), but the industry is constantly given a bad name despite the amazing products that are being built.

"Crime season" is quite possibly the worst marketing for an industry that thrives on belief.

Even though the "good" projects and the "bad" projects are seperate entities, it all gets intertwined.

LUNA & FTX already screwed retail.

We slowly built the belief back over 2 years, only for politicians/celebrities/scammers to take advantage and extract billions.

Decentralisation maxis will say it's a free market, and the blockchain can be used for whatever purpose people see fit. And I agree fundamentally. But it's a double edged sword, because without proper regulation the tech will continue to be used for exploitation. And the big players in the market (certain exchanges, VCs, MMs etc.) are also enabling this (not all, I know some amazing VCs/exchanges - but all it takes is a few enablers to do damage).

And yeah, you can make a lot of money from playing these short-term games, and I personally have made money trading this stuff (as we're essentially forced to as traders in the pursuit of gains), but it comes at a cost.

It's fundamentally the reason why alts overall are performing so poorly. People don't believe anymore, they're jaded and feel like the game is rigged against them.

Eventually, I believe that nature is healing and the market will course-correct, but until then we might have to deal with a little more pain.

Unfortunately, it feels like: 

2021 = the belief cycle
2025 = the scam cycle

@TitanTokens @MAS_sg I am. My hope is that some $OM community members that are still bullish on RWA (as you should be), give it more of a look.

The $OM dump is one of the biggest single day wipeouts in crypto history ($5.2b of market cap erased in 24 hours), but there are some very good lessons here:

‚Ä¢ Market caps are an illusion: Liquidity is more important than the valuation itself. Most valuations in crypto are thin air
‚Ä¢ If something smells off (especially PA wise), it probably is, the chart didn‚Äôt look ‚Äúnormal‚Äù for some time (something I began to point out in my videos/AMAs over the past few months)
‚Ä¢ There is a big differential between fundamentals and price across the board in crypto - relative valuations only work when there is a very comparable product/revenue
‚Ä¢ Raises a bigger question: If valuations are largely fugazi - how many other top projects could this happen to? The floor for most alts is eventually 0 (although most won't go there quickly, assuming there's manipulation - this is one of the rare cases where it's prevalent on a major token)

For more context, my story with the token: I invested in OM at the start of 2024, publicly rode it from $0.30 to $3. I sold ‚Äúearly‚Äù because I felt like it was entering overvalued territory (a feeling I shared publicly many times as well as in @mileshighclub_) - afterwards, it ran even higher to my surprise (which ultimately was good for my viewers as it extended the profit taking window even further). Was still one of my best RWA trades this cycle alongside $ONDO at $0.20 liquid (+ seed), which I also technically TPd too ‚Äúearly‚Äù. But overall, as a rule of thumb, it‚Äôs better to sell too early than too late.

In terms of price action on OM now, it‚Äôs hard to get a read - there‚Äôs an argument it could be a buy if the team responds well, but I probably won‚Äôt take the risk with meaningful size as I prefer confirmation/trend trades in this market. Definitely worth monitoring/charting tho.

On the flip side, if trust does end up being eroded - it could be a bullish tailwind for other leading RWA protocols, as liquidity will need to flow somewhere whenever people speculate on RWA. It's not a trend I see going away any time soon.

Crypto developer activity is the lowest it's been since 2018.

This is probably the saddest chart in crypto, and also the one which most accurately depicts the current state of the industry.

Even in the 2022 bear market, developers kept building.

But what are the reasons for this?
1. The elephant in the room: AI is much more exciting, and talented developers see more opportunity harnessing their skills elsewhere
‚Ä¢ In 2017 and 2021, crypto was the new kid on the block - but the public excitement surrounding AI has comparatively trumped it
2. Although $BTC prices are much higher, VC funding has significantly dried up since 2023, partly due to the valuation mis-match between private and public markets (which has triggered more conservative investment behaviour)
3. The technology probably hasn't advanced as fast as some would've hoped - we do have use cases which are proving to have strong PMF (i.e. stables & RWA)
4. Users don't really intrinsically value decentralisation - most people just want a good experience, so the appeal of building on crypto rails has  slightly diminished

All this being said, there are still a lot of really exciting verticals (like synergies with AI, stables, RWA), and clearly BTC is in the best spot it's ever been - but we need to accept that the industry has significantly shifted over the past couple of years - and the develop numbers reflect this.

Will there ever be an "alt season" again?

Seeing a lot of discussion about this on the TL.

Here are my thoughts.

Firstly, it depends on your definition of "alt season". If you're referring to the index, then yes, I expect it to spike again at some point this year.

If you're referring to the multi-month up only mania of 2021, then no. The unique combination of QE/stimulus and V-shaped equities repricing created conditions that are almost impossible to replicate. Expecting that is a recipe for disaster. Key word here: "expecting".

If a larger "alt season" DOES happen, great. That makes our job a lot easier, and complacency won't be punished as much.

Go in with the mindset of the rotation into alts being short-lived (this will force you to take profits). It may not actually be short-lived, but at least you're securing profits. Remember, taking profits early is better than not at all.

If not, you should have other frameworks to make money on alts (i.e. thinking of the market as multiple mini-cycles/pockets of narrative outperformance).

TLDR:
‚Ä¢ Have a framework where you're not reliant on a 2021-esque alt-season (and be pleasantly surprised if it does).
‚Ä¢ This cycle is materially different from the last (as each cycle is), expecting a repetition is dangerous.
‚Ä¢ Specific assets/sectors are going to have crazy runs when conditions allow it.
‚Ä¢ Instead of holding everything and everything, have a more concentrated basket of high-conviction assets.
‚Ä¢ Juxtapose those holdings with the willingness to trade in profitable playgrounds (i.e. AI) - but treat them as trades, don't bag hold.
The risk of a life of mediocrity is still greater than the risk of playing the game.

Don't let this discourage you.

Liquidity will still concentrate into the hottest narratives.

You just need to:

‚Ä¢ Be more selective with what you hold, and why you hold it (lazy holds won't work)

‚Ä¢ Rely more on PA invalidations (still the best way to gauge momentum shift)

Idk how people can expect an "everything up only" alt season like 2021 when there is 10000000x the amount of tokens this cycle.

In theory, even IF there was the same amount of liquidity entering the market as 2021, it would be more dispersed, meaning smaller moves per alt.

Everyone knows if you win the first hour of the day, you'll usually win the rest of the day.

But most people still wake up with zero structure.

If you're struggling to have productive days, this AI prompting framework builds a morning routine that transforms your productivity.üëá

Step 1. Define the desired outcome of your morning routine

Before building the structure, you need to clarify what this routine is supposed to do for you.

Full prompt: You are my clarity coach. Help me define the core outcome I want to achieve from my morning routine. This is not about what tasks I complete, but about how I want to feel, how I want to show up, and what kind of momentum I want to build for the rest of the day. Based on my current challenges (insert what‚Äôs not working) and what I want more of (insert what you‚Äôre aiming for), guide me to craft a single, clear sentence that captures the purpose of my morning routine. This sentence will shape every step that comes next, so make it specific, motivating, and aligned with how I want to live.

Step 2. Lock in your non-negotiables

Now that you have the goal set within the LLM, define your morning non-negotiables.

Full prompt: "You are now my morning routine strategist. I have three non-negotiables that I want built into every morning, no matter how much time or energy I have. These are: (insert non-negotiable 1), (insert non-negotiable 2), and (insert non-negotiable 3). Use these to design the core structure of my morning with my goal from step 1 in mind."

Step 3. Build the system

Now that GPT understands your desired outcome and your non-negotiables, have it design a focused, friction-free routine you can run on most days.

Full prompt: "You are now my routine builder. Based on my desired outcome from Step 1 and my non-negotiables from Step 2, design a 30-minute morning routine I can follow consistently. Structure it in a way that builds momentum for the rest of the day. Each action should connect directly to one of the non-negotiables and be easy to complete, even on low-energy days. Format the routine as a clear, step-by-step checklist,"

Step 4. Build a flexible fallback system

Not every morning goes as planned. Use GPT to build a fallback version of your routine that keeps your core intact, even when life happens.

Full prompt: "Using my goal from Step 1, the non-negotiables from Step 2, and the system we built in Step 3, create a simplified version of my morning routine that I can run on low-energy or unpredictable days. This version should take 10‚Äì15 minutes max; keep my most important habits alive. Format it as a short checklist with flexible timing, this routine should focus on my highest-leverage tasks and cut some fluff from Step 3."

Bookmark this to increase your daily productivity.

Full summary of what just happened with Trump's tariffs, what I think happens next, and the big looming unknowns.üëá

What happened:
‚Ä¢ Trump orders a 90-day tariff pause, with a lower reciprocal tariff of 10% for all nations except China
‚Ä¢ Just hours prior, Trump posted that it's a "great time to buy"
‚Ä¢ Raised tariff on China to 125%, effective immediately (trade war is basically US vs China now)

My take:
‚Ä¢ The tariff can will likely continue to be kicked down the road beyond the 90-days
‚Ä¢ Main negative is that tariff resolution is now stretched into the mid-term, which creates a slight overhang vs fully resolving now (even though it would've been immediately more painful)
‚Ä¢ On one hand, this definitely improves the short-term outlook of the market (gives us real runway for relief for the first time in a while), but on the other hand - more pain in the short-term would've led to much more aggressive monetary policy longer-term (rate cuts, QE)

Unknowns:
‚Ä¢ Is the market fully pricing in a China deal? If not, and one comes - market would likely explode
‚Ä¢ A lot of this hinges on China's willingness to negotiate with the U.S.
‚Ä¢ How will allies handle the 10% rate? Will supply chains reroute fast enough to dodge China‚Äôs fallout?

TLDR: From a market POV: Better short term, potentially worse long term.

My approach to the market has changed a lot this year.

The main one being opting to hold more cash (~50%+ at all times) as opposed to fully allocating into spot.

Despite what CT tells you, you don't need to be fully allocated to make big gains in the market.üëá

There are a few reasons I am playing the game this way (not for everyone, but I'll elaborate on my own strategy):

1. As most rotations are a lot shorter nowadays, I prefer having high liquidity. For example, I took a big Launchcoin position the other week, and it were easy for me to make a high conviction trade due to being liquid. If I had been allocated to 90% alts, I would've had to have sold other positions (perhaps at inopportune times), to fund the trade. This is suboptimal.

2. I feel a lot more emotionally in control. One thing I've learnt about myself, is that I am a good trend spotter/have a good natural feel for the market, but bad emotionally at executing my ideas. Since being more liquid, I've found myself able to play out my theses with less mental baggage.

3. I can still catch the meat of the moves rather than trying to pre-empt a rotation before it begins. By jumping on narrative trains after the first breakout, or after seeing an increase in mindshare + higher lows on the chart, I still expose myself to the upside of a move without the mental torment of experiencing huge drawdowns waiting for a move that never comes. Yes, there is an obvious trade-off here (making a slightly smaller multiple vs people who just stack and hold), but I am comfortable with that in many cases - and often the smaller gains on the winners offset the losers you run into implementing an aggressive buy-and-hold strategy.

4. Despite the above points, I am still allocated 50% to the market. Why? Because I don't want to be sidelined entirely, especially to coins I have strong conviction will pump at some point in the cycle (i.e. AI, RWA, stablecoin + DeFi proxies). By balancing both sides of my portfolio as a barbell, I'm able to hold these positions whilst feeling protected due to my cash position. On big dips, this serves as a) a hedge against downside, and b) allows me to take advantage of dips whilst others panic (a good example of this was when $BTC hit $75k during the Tariff FUD, when I publicly made my biggest BTC buy ever).

Do I think this approach is optimal for all? No.

You need to understand your own psychology and learn what works for you.

Your strategy also depends on a variety of factors such as your edge, risk tolerance, time horizon, time, portfolio size etc.

But hopefully this post serves as food for thought, and teaches you that you can still make money in this market without being 100% risk on, despite what CT makes you believe sometimes.

One of my key criteria for holding an altcoin in these conditions is minimal token unlocks.

Momentum is already against us - I don't need to compound the issue by holding heavily debasing altcoins.

"Bullish unlocks" are a real thing in a bull-market, but "bearish unlocks" are equally as true in a down trend.

(there are some exceptions of course, but the majority of your holdings should have minimal sell pressure).

The good thing about crypto (vs more mature markets) is the prevalence of asymmetries.

Makes it easier to develop an edge, but you still need to put in the work to do so.

I suggest picking one niche and going all-in, instead of spreading your attention far and wide.

9. Don't plan on holding any altcoin long term.

Altcoin "investing" is kind of a myth.

Your default mindset should be that you're "trading" an altcoin vs its USD pair whenever you're buying.

I like this mindset as it also formalises the need to set a clear TP/invalidation plan. Whereas "investors" can be lazy with this stuff. "Investing" isn't an excuse for poor risk management".

Now that "trade" could be 3 days, 3 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, in some cases even 12 months.

But be clear with yourself that it's just that - a trade, with the goal of either compounding more $BTC or more capital.

8. Don't borrow conviction.

Whenever I have bought on a coin based on someone else's thesis (and not my own), it has ended badly.

Use other people for ideas - but verify them yourself and build your own beliefs.

Otherwise you'll end up holding bags with no real conviction and/or idea of what to do when that conviction is tested.

7. Always set invalidations.

Towards the end of the year I got much better at this.

But there were still times (especially during March 2024), where stronger invalidations would've prevented a lot of pain.

It can be as simple as having a pre-determined HTF support level/moving average, where you de-risk on the break of structure.

It can also be more advanced, like identifying a LTF loss of momentum, and getting back in on a show of strength. In trending markets, this works well.

But at least have some sort of invalidation plan in place, instead of bag-holding an entire stack to 0.

6. F*ck price targets or profit targets.

The market doesn't care about your arbitrary price target, whether it be a specific dollar value or a multiple.

Chasing targets is a sure-fire way to round-trip profits.

And if you do somehow hit your goal, sell. Don't get greedy and shift your goalposts. Or at the very least, chase the new goalposts with a smaller stack, and protect your principle.

5. Compound slowly.

Most mistakes in the market fundamentally come from the pursuit of quick (and "easy") gains.

But building wealth long term really just boils down to consistently compounding small profits over time.

Treat each trade as a "bet", with the aim of adding to your overall stack (like poker).

4. Treat every dollar with respect.

I read this tweet the other day, and it hit home.

For some reason in crypto sometimes we completely lose our value-for-money perception.

For example: There was a trade where I round-tripped $1.7M in December, and I wish I had just half of that now.

Whereas at the time I found myself not valuing money, because you get so conditioned to the euphoric conditions.

Never lose perspective (even during crazy times), and value every dollar. Because there will come a day where you will value such dollar even more.

3. Complacency kills.

There were times where I convinced myself I was taking profits, but in reality I wasn't taking enough.

"ah yes, I'll take another $100k off the table today - look at me, mum! I'm taking profits!"

*whilst still holding millions in sh*tcoins*

I found myself looking at my portfolio value as reassurance, as opposed to the actual stablecoin weighting of that portfolio - which is the more important metric in terms of retaining wealth.

2. Take profits out of crypto entirely.

There were many times I took profits into stables, only to end up using those stables on chasing the next play.

However, the money I off-ramped to fiat, or other "real" investments, was inaccessible (i.e. "safe").

I suppose it also depends on your temperament. I'm ADHD - so the more measures I can introduce to prevent impulsive decisions (and make myself think), the better.

1. It's better to sell too early than too late.

I've never regretted taking profits on a coin, whereas there have been many times where I've regretted NOT taking profits on a coin.

It's better to incrementally TP, than sell too late and end up round-tripping.

This cycle, I did much better, and was able to keep a decent chunk of my gains, but still round-tripped much more than I would've liked.

13. You DON'T need to be an expert before you start posting.

In the beginning, treat X as your personal journal.

Most people wait until they're "ready."  But, your beginner's perspective is valuable because you remember what it's like not to understand.

Start documenting what you're learning right now, as this is how you become an "expert."

I learnt so much just through creating posts/videos. It also helps your learning process.

Think of it as public learning, or a public journal.

12. Topic and packaging are everything.

Without a compelling "hook" (first line(s)), your post won't go viral.

Even with great insights, if you don't catch eyeballs, your content is dead on arrival.

With the variety of LLMs available now, there's no excuse here (just make sure to humanise it and add your own twist).

11. Spread your posts out.

Give your tweets room to breathe.

If you post five bangers back-to-back, they'll compete. Let each piece build its own momentum before posting the next.

You can use a scheduling tool like Typefully or TweetHunter to help organise and schedule ideas.

10. Funnel from other platforms.

Many use X to grow their YT channels, but few leverage YT/TikTok/IG to boost their X presence.

By posting short clips of your content, you can direct viewers to your X.

It's an underutilized strategy that amplifies growth across platforms.

I remember Becker did well funneling from YT > X last cycle.

9. Do what others won't.

Most people are lazy.

The higher the barrier to entry on the content you're creating, the bigger the moat.

i.e.

- Video content? Hard.
- Tutorials? Hard.
- Threads/long form? Harder than short tweets
- Custom infographics? Hard.

This stuff can really set your brand apart.

8. Don't fake engagement.

The X algorithm is more intelligent than you think.

Your engagement rate is important to get tweet distribution.

7. Be intentional with your audience.

Building a high-quality audience opens doors to future opportunities.

Even if you don't know what those opportunities are, as a general rule, you want to attract higher-quality people.

6. Focus on providing VALUE first.

There are three ways to provide raw value:

‚Ä¢ Share information that no one else is discussing
‚Ä¢ Share information more efficiently
‚Ä¢ Add your unique perspective/knowledge

Choose one method to differentiate yourself from the crowd, and stick with it.

5. Be a reply guy (in a smart way).

Make a list of the leading accounts in your niche.

Reply to their posts every day with valuable insights, as well as adding your perspective.

The goal here is to add value, not just to get noticed.

Funnily enough, I've actually ended up hiring multiple people who reply guy'd me for a long period of time. It works.

4. Push through the early growing pains.

The first 10K followers are undoubtedly the hardest.

Initially, engagement on your account will be minimal or near zero.

One trick to overcome this is to engage with large accounts by providing actionable and alpha-packed insights.

Reaching 10k makes the road to 100k much easier.

3. Create content on viral topics.

Ideally, your niche crosses over with a topic that has strong attention/mindshare.

I was lucky that DeFi was super hot in 2020/21.

You want to create content on things people are actually interested in reading about.

2. Post consistently.

More is better (as long as you can maintain a good quality standard).

Even during the '22 bear market, I was posting threads daily at one point.

The X algorithm rewards consistency.

1. Pick a niche and go all in.

If you want to stand out and build authority, you first need to become and expert in, and own, one specific angle - as opposed to becoming another generalist.

I chose DeFi as my initial area of focus when I began creating content.

Allocating all your resources to one niche is the most optimal way to ensure your content stands out, which in turn will reach a wider audience over time as you expand.

I grew my X account to 600k+ in 4 years.

Most people set goals, but never end up achieving them.

This is because they have the wrong mindset.

The truth is: You‚Äôre already the person you want to be - you just haven‚Äôt stepped into that version yet.

This powerful prompting framework simulates conversations with your future self to help you close the gap more quickly.üëá

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Step 1: Simulate your future self + set the role

Before anything else, define who you're becoming.

You‚Äôre not talking to a generic ‚Äúbetter you.‚Äù You‚Äôre conversing with the version of you who already solved your current challenge.

Full prompt: "I want to have a conversation with my future self, exactly (insert time frame ahead). In that future, I‚Äôve already overcome (insert major challenge) and unlocked the next level in (insert area of growth such as career, mindset, health, etc). Play the role of this future version of me and speak to me like a mentor who understands what I‚Äôm experiencing right now."

Step 2: Future self questions present you

Now that you've established the role with the model, have "future you" ask some deep questions.

Full prompt: "Now act as my future self from (insert time frame ahead). You‚Äôve already achieved (insert milestone or transformation). Ask me a series of introspective questions to help me uncover blind spots, limiting habits, or assumptions that are keeping me stuck. These questions should push me to reflect deeply and challenge how I currently think, work, and behave."

Step 3: Generate the upgrade path

Now that your future self has helped surface blind spots and mental bottlenecks, it's time to turn those insights into an actionable path.

Full prompt: "Based on this conversation with my future self and the questions they asked me, help me generate a practical upgrade path. Outline the 3 to 5 most important mindset shifts, daily habits, or decisions I need to make to become this version of myself faster. Frame each one as a clear, high-leverage move I can begin this week. Prioritize simplicity and momentum, not perfection."

Step 4: Build a future-self action tracker

Now that you've clarified your actionable roadmap, turn it into a system to measure long-term alignment.

Full prompt: "Based on the upgrade path we just outlined, create a simple, weekly action tracker that helps me stay accountable to my future self. Include categories for key behaviors I need to reinforce, habits to break, and any weekly reflection questions that will help me course-correct. Organize it in a clear table format that I can review every Sunday. Make it easy to scan but powerful enough to track whether I'm living in alignment with the person I want to become."

Some tips with this framework:

‚Ä¢ Keep using the same chat so you can talk to "future you" anytime you want
‚Ä¢ Continuously add context to the model about who the ideal "future you" really is - the more context the model has, the better the outputs will be
‚Ä¢ Create a dedicated project/folder- this allows you to add custom instructions and documents to the conversations you have with your future self

I find it ridiculous when people ridicule traders for "flip-flopping"

In fact, you SHOULD be regularly assessing your position based on new information

For example:

If you're playing poker

And you start with Ace-King of spades

You might bet aggressively, because it's +EV to do so

But if the flops comes 3 hearts, and your opponent raises significantly

Are your odds still as good as they were a minute ago?

No

The same concept applies in crypto

As new information comes in, it dynamically changes your odds of success (in both a macro sense and in regards to specific trades

New information matters (a lot)

And you should absolutely be adapting to it

The quicker you are to adapt, the better

This doesn't justify baseless "flip-flopping"

You're simply re-calculating your EV at all times based on new information, and positioning accordingly

I have high conviction that $BTC will make a new ATH sometime between Q3 this year and Q1 2026.

Yes, it's painful now - but I think people are missing the bigger picture, and the eventual rally will be bigger than ever.

My rationale:

‚Ä¢ Trump's plan is to cause short-term pain now as he tries to send the dollar/yields lower (we're currently in the process of the market digesting the new baseline)
‚Ä¢ Mid term case is tariffs will force domestic absorption of treasuries to offset the reduction in foreign buying (BTC is extremely sensitive to global liquidity)
‚Ä¢ The market will likely bottom on recession fears (it's a scary word and markets hate uncertainty), but by the time it officially comes around the market will already be looking at the FED's response
‚Ä¢ The FED will eventually be forced to cut rates, paving the way for QE potentially in 2026 (remember markets are forward looking, and imo QE is arguably less important this year than other liquidity measures - they have options: repo ops, BTFP, buying treasuries etc.)
‚Ä¢ As for alts, the top quality stuff will likely follow BTC's trajectory and find a floor before recovering - bad stuff will die out, and "alt season" (whatever that looks like next time) will likely only occur once BTC has peaked or is close to a peak (as is almost always the case). Also plenty of money to be made on the way up if you're savvy and identify the top trends. 
‚Ä¢ Remember, in tighter liquidity environments, market participants tend to consolidate around higher quality assets (BTC first), before rotating down the risk curve once confidence and liquidity improve - you can front run this slightly, but not so much that you run the risk of underperforming for months in the lead up (bad R/R). 

As for the short term, anything can happen. Trying to forecast anything in the 1-12 week range is extremely difficult right now, and is largely a fools game.

There are definitely bearish arguments to be made too, which I deliberately left out here to emphasise my long-term thesis, but i may do a follow up post later outlining some of the risks.

Overall, I'm playing a much longer-term game with my positioning: DCAing $BTC, select equities that are hit hard by the trade war fears but still have good fundamentals, and quality alts if the technicals align (many setups don't yet, but they will over the coming months). 

It's not easy to be patient, but it's what is required right now.

Instead of tinkering around too much with my portfolio, and chopping myself up, I'm being super strategic and spending more time on other interesting things like AI-implementation into my personal life/business. So when crazy-mode comes back I'll be even more optimised and efficient.

But I definitely am looking at increasing risk exposure over the coming weeks/months as I have conviction that these entires will look pretty good in hindsight come Q1 next year.

The biggest killer in crypto is the "head in the sand" mentality.

This is something I've struggled with this cycle, and has inadvertently cost me millions. 

When times are good, it's easy to get caught up in euphoria and get complacent in terms of locking in profits/spotting warning signs. 

When times are bad, it's easy to "bury your head in the sand", not check your portfolio, and get complacent with managing your portfolio - even though these are the times where you really need to be paying attention (spotting opportunities to buy + de-risk when necessary).

You need to stay objective at all times and constantly re-evaluate the risks/opportunities. Complacency kills.

In principle, all this sounds simple, but you do need a basic knowledge of how to read price action and execute.

And importantly, the mental fortitude to stick to a plan.

Most people fail because they get too emotional and are unable to execute their intended strategy.

Once structure shifts from bearish (downtrend) to bullish (uptrend), you have 2 options.

1. Get in on a break of structure (clearing the prior range high), or

2. Buy pullbacks (bullish continuation with invalidations below prior lows).

It's better to cut quick on the confirmation of a lower low, and get back in on a new confirmed uptrend, than running the risk of exposing yourself to further downside.

UPTREND

Generally speaking, this is the "safest" time to buy an altcoin.

The hardest part is getting the right execution and not FOMOing into pumps. You still want to maintain clear invalidations. https://t.co/dyXmEnKhpi

Many alts won't even go through accumulation.

We're seeing a market-wide cleanse, where some alts will die as they fail to find a floor.

If an altcoin DOES show signs of finding a floor, it's a good sign (albeit not foolproof), that it has a higher likelihood of making a comeback during an up-trending market.

ACCUMULATION

Once price starts to settle, this is a sign of seller exhaustion.

If price continuously respects a particular level (forming a range low), you can bid this level and cut below if needed (invalidation). https://t.co/mrRtmFk8K8

Personally, I don't like being underwater - so the alts I'm currently DCAing into are extremely limited.

For the rest, I'm following the next 2 phases (accumulation + uptrend).üëá

This is ok for coins that you have extremely high conviction in, that you think will inevitably end up coming back at some point.

However, you have to be very careful with this - as you need extreme mental fortitude to manage being underwater for extended periods of time.

DOWNTREND

This is the current trend we're in.

You want to AVOID buying here.

The issue with downtrends, is you have no idea when they're going to end.

So even if you buy every dip, your cost basis can end up being quite high if the market keeps dipping. https://t.co/90bx9XXrVD
