Although we may not be exactly following past cycles, I'm still optimistic that with the right mindset and approach, there is still lots of upside in 2025.

Even though we are currently in a bear phase, momentum at some point will shift and create many new opportunities.

Your goal until then is to survive. Crypto rewards those who are able to stay in the game despite enduring volatility.

One of the key points I highlighted in this post is the importance of having an INVALIDATION criteria for each trade, just as you would have a validation for why you're buying a coin in the first place.

I see far too many people entering positions with absolutely no concept of risk management/invalidation.

If there's one tip that you can implement right now, that will drastically improve your profitability going forward, it's the importance of having a technical and/or fundamental invalidation for each position.

Your conviction/time horizon of a specific trade may impact where/how you invalidate, but it doesn't change the fact that you need a plan in place.
If you're holding a bloated crypto portfolio, and are unsure of how to maneuver - last week I wrote a guide on how you can adapt your portfolio to the changing market conditions.

The way I'm structuring my portfolio is 50% long-term high conviction plays, and 50% allocated in stables/active trades, which I use to go in-and-out of opportunities as they arise.

I'm denominating all my trades in stables as a metric to judge my success over time, taking profits back into stables every time I exit a trade.

There's a reason why so many of crypto's greatest traders/minds are ex-poker pros (Jordi included), because it teaches you to think in bets and consider the probabilistic outcomes of each trade.

@game_for_one has a great post on this subject.

A bunch of small wins over a sustained period of time = a much bigger long-term win overall.

So instead of going all-out trying to "make it" by relying on "alt season" to multiply your portfolio, try and consistently compound wealth over time.

Small bet > take profits, another bet > take profits and so on.

I had dinner with @gametheorizing the other night, and he made a great point.

Everyone is so focused on an end goal: Whether it be 5xing, 10xing or 20xing their portfolio.

BUT, it's actually better to adopt a mindset where you simply focus on making multiple smaller bets vs one big hail mary.
So this leads me to the next section of this thread: My strategy.

Within these bubbles, there are tons of opportunities to make money.

In 2024, we saw memes in November, AI in December, agents in January, and there will no doubt be another trend which emerges soon.

If you're savvy, these are great money making opportunities - but require a slightly different approach than past cycles.

The good news: Just as there's no 4-year cycle, this also means there won't be painful multi-year bear markets either (triggered by crypto specific variables - of course it's possible from a macro POV, as crypto doesn't operate in a vacuum and we are more correlated to macro than ever before).

Risk on vs risk off periods in the market are likely going to be driven by changes in macro conditions, which trigger mini echo-bubbles, as opposed to a multi-month up-only-esque rally.

My ultimate due diligence checklist I complete BEFORE BUYING any coin.

If you can answer each question, you'll already be ahead of 99% of crypto investors in terms of DD - and you'll significantly increase your strike rate.

(bookmark this post, and answer each question before buying any coin).

General:
‚Ä¢ What's their USP?
‚Ä¢ Is there product market fit?
‚Ä¢ Does it have a strong community?
‚Ä¢ Is the narrative compelling and in line with the market?
‚Ä¢ Do they have a strong moat/competitive advantage?
‚Ä¢ Are there other comparable projects "anchoring" the price? (upside gauge)
‚Ä¢ Are there trusted influencers or thought leaders backing the project? (not just paid shills)?
‚Ä¢ What's their roadmap/end goal?
‚Ä¢ How far away are they from their end goal?
‚Ä¢ Are there any obvious red flags? (bundled supply, rug risk, honeypot etc.)
‚Ä¢ Have their smart contracts been audited? Are the audits publicly available?
‚Ä¢ Are they on CEXs?
‚Ä¢ Do they fulfill enough criteria to get on CEXs? (volume, market cap, community)

Tokenomics:
‚Ä¢ What is the token's primary utility in the ecosystem? Is it essential for the protocol's function?
‚Ä¢ What's the market cap to FDV ratio?
‚Ä¢ Are the tokenomics conducive to value accrual?
‚Ä¢ Are they generating fees/real revenue?
‚Ä¢ Is it inflationary or deflationary?
‚Ä¢ What's the vesting schedule?
‚Ä¢ Where are the unlocks going?
‚Ä¢ Is there a long term plan to alter the tokenomics?

Team:
‚Ä¢ Is the team doxxed?
‚Ä¢ Do they have a solid track record?
‚Ä¢ Does the project have reputable advisors with relevant expertise?
‚Ä¢ Are there any AMAs or interviews you can listen to, to get a better gauge?
‚Ä¢ Have they historically hit their roadmap checkpoints/goals?
‚Ä¢ Do they have any reputable partnerships or collaborations with established players in the space?

Technical:
‚Ä¢ Is price action exhibiting relative strength to the rest of the market?
‚Ä¢ Is price at or above a key support level?
‚Ä¢ Is it in an uptrend  (higher lows and higher highs)?
‚Ä¢ Is there a clear HTF indicator/level that could serve as an invalidation point?

On-chain:
‚Ä¢ Are there significant whale wallets? What‚Äôs their behavior (accumulation or distribution)?
‚Ä¢ What‚Äôs the ratio of whale wallets to retail wallets?
‚Ä¢ How liquid is the token?
‚Ä¢ How many unique wallets interact with the token daily?
‚Ä¢ Has the holder base been sustainably growing over time?

It might take more time, but if you can answer each one of these questions, you're going to be MUCH better positioned to make a decision regarding investing in a project.

99% of people don't do this, so it will put you in the minority and you'll have a huge information advantage.

If you're worried about AI storing your data (ChatGPT, Gemini etc.), here are some good security practices:

2. Use an email not connected to your name

"Trust me you can do better on your own" - I used to think so, until I started digging deep. Then I realised how powerful these models are. It's life-changing stuff.

How to change your entire life in one weekend:

Lock yourself in a room for 2 days with ChatGPT. 

You‚Äôll come out with a blueprint that could make you unrecognisable in a year.

Here's exactly how (10 steps): 

1. Block out all distractions for 2 days. Cancel all plans.

2. Spend the entire weekend promoting. Feed an LLM your whole life, including:
‚Ä¢ Business plans
‚Ä¢ Financial situation
‚Ä¢ Issues
‚Ä¢ Strengths/weaknesses
‚Ä¢ Goals

Keep asking it to ask you questions. Answer so many questions you're sick of answering questions. 

Keep prompting after each batch: "Ask me 10 more follow up questions based on my answers. We're trying to paint a full picture of my life. Don't answer anything yet."

3. Once the quality of the questions significantly deteriorates/you start getting rephrased repetitive questions, it's a sign you've sent enough info (I'm not kidding, this takes more than a day in many cases - use voice memos to make it easier and more natural). 

4. Let's say you used ChatGPT's o3 for this, now ask it to compile the ENTIRE chat history into a PDF. 

5. Take that PDF, and send it to Gemini & Perplexity.

6. Get both of these LLMs to ask questions that o3 missed. Spend another few hours doing that using previously mentioned prompt.

7. Then, get them to create 2 additional PDFs with respective summaries, and combine all 3 to create a master PDF.

8. Now, prompt all 3 LLMs with that master PDF.

"This file contains an entire summary of my life. You now know more about me than any human ever has. Based on this file, give me brutally honest, life-altering feedback. Tell me my biggest strengths, my deepest weaknesses, hidden blind spots, and the beliefs holding me back. Then give me a strategic plan to optimize my career, relationships, health, and mindset over the next 12 months. No fluff. Be direct. Be detailed. Change my life.‚Äù

9. Based on the one which gives the best response (in my experience Gemini, but o3 is also pretty good), ask a serious of follow up questions to nail the specifics of each facet of your life. Whether it be a business plan, relationship plan, or another aspect important to you.

10. Then, get it to create a document with an exact step-by-step plan to improve your life. A comprehensive blueprint to change your life.

What about inflation? Opportunity cost?

Well, there are 2 reasons (which are very specific to me and my goals): 

1. In our industry (and in private equity - where I have an increasing focus), you need liquidity to go big when there's a strong +EV opportunity. You don't want to be forced to sell a risk-asset at the wrong time to fund a better opportunity.

2. I could park my money in the S&P500 and get 10% a year, or I could park in T-bills at 4.3%, and have the freedom to inject money into my businesses/building new products as I see fit. If I'm over allocated to risk assets, and there is an opportunity to grow my business, once again - I may be forced to sell at an inopportune time.

These 2 factors are very individualised to my situation, so the average person probably shouldn't follow this strategy.

However, there is something to be said for spending more money investing in yourself vs the markets. We've been conditioned to thinking investing is the key to wealth - but it's really your income.

When is the time to start buying altcoins again?

Well, it depends on the price action of the specific alt.

There are 3 phases of price action: Downtrend, accumulation, uptrend.

Downtrend: You want to absolutely AVOID buying here. Most alts are in downtrends right now. Don't catch knives. 

Accumulation: Once price starts to settle, this is a sign of seller exhaustion. If price continuously respects a particular level (range low), you can bid this level and cut below (invalidation).

Uptrend: Once structure shifts from bearish (downtrend) to bullish (uptrend) you can get back in on either a) a break of structure, or b) bullish continuation pullbacks.

I'm personally following these guidelines for any altcoin purchase/spot trade over the coming months.

Remove these phrases from your vocabulary:

‚Ä¢ Bull market
‚Ä¢ Bear market
‚Ä¢ Alt season 
‚Ä¢ Cycle
‚Ä¢ 4-year cucle

This is a different market now.

@Overdose_AI $5,000 originally to buy my first $BTC in 2019.

But averaged in another $50k in 2020/21.

A ‚Äúbear market‚Äù could last 2 months if a sudden catalyst injects liquidity.

Or 4 months. Or 4 weeks.

The term itself is meaningless. Just like a ‚Äúbull market‚Äù might not be as long or parabolic as many expect.

Focus on liquidity, not labels.

"Bear market", "bull market", "cycle".

All these terms are irrelevant right now.

Markets are driven by liquidity (lights on vs lights off).

Prices go down when liquidity dries up. 

Prices go up when liquidity is injected.

Timeframes don't matter. Liquidity does.

Ironically, the $1m I put into watches/cars this cycle (that some people called me "dumb" for at the time), ended up being a nice hedge. üòÇ

I can still sell for minimal depreciation and theoretically buy back into the market if needed.

Lesson: If you make money in crypto, take some out, it can be into fiat, property, luxury items, basically anything "real".

Holding too many stables tempts you into taking bigger risk, which at the peak of the bull can lead to some pretty damaging decisions (as is what happened to me in December).

Doing anything truly meaningful is really hard.

Despite what X might tell you, most successful people worked relentlessly and faced multiple setbacks along the way.

Put your head down and work hard consistently. The results will come.

Market cap ‚â† liquidity.

Most valuations in crypto are fugazi.

ZEREBRO being valued at $800m is not the same as a tech stock being valued at $800m.

If someone wanted to extract $20m at the time, they would crater the price - as there is not enough liquidity to absorb a sell at that time.

Whereas stocks are much more liquid, and there are more counterparties to step in and absorb a big sell.

Liquidity is much more important than market cap when it comes to realising a trade.

- BTC dominance closes below 60% on the weekly timeframe.

- Sustained growth in Google Trends for "ai crypto" searches and stablecoin inflows (8% QoQ).

We know we're currently in a choppy phase, but we need to start preparing for when "alt season" arrives.

Things can change quickly.

So, these are the exact triggers we need to watch to determine when "alt season" could take place, allowing you to pre-empt instead of feeling FOMO.

Remember, the most fun happens between 0.7>1.

The end of the move is the most explosive.

So where are we NOW?

But first, let's break down each of the 4 pillars to provide more context.

Each pillar was backdated to test for effectiveness, combined with the new market thesis based on current dynamics.

The scoring method works as follows:

Each pillar is classified as red, yellow, or green, according to its current status.

A score of 0 is assigned for red, 0.5 for yellow, and 1.0 for green.

When the total weighted score = >0.70, it's alt season.

I'll reveal our current status later in this thread.

I built the Alt Season Readiness Score (ARS) model on ChatGPT to quantify this theory with real data.

It relies on 4 core pillars:

- BTC.d (weighted at 35%)
- ETH/BTC (25%)
- Altseason Index (20%)
- Narrative & Liquidity Pulse (20%)

Each pillar gets scored and combined for a real-time altseason score.

THE "ALT SEASON 3.0" THESIS:

This cycle will be represented by shorter, sharper, and heavily sector-selective rotations, as opposed to one big "everything goes up only" period.

Read the full core thesis below. https://t.co/k7nzpt0GRl

Given the above factors, I think that if we experience another alt season, it would look vastly different from the previous ones.

That's why I developed my "Alt Season 3.0" thesis, recognising that we need to adjust our mental models and thinking behind Alt Season, and how it will likely represent this cycle.

3. Retail got rekt

Retail participation is at its lowest level in a long time.

This is a combination of:

-  People getting rekt in 2021 and not coming back (big cohort),  UST/FTX didn't help
- People getting rekt on Pump Fun/memes in late 2024, many are wary
- No real reasons beyond "BTC is pumping" to be structurally bullish on alts, or get excited about the tech (aside from instances of PMF i.e. HYPE).

2. The institutionalisation of $BTC

The traditional flow of funds (BTC > ETH > alts) has been disrupted due to the introduction of the ETFs.

The classic wealth effect we saw in past cycles is no longer a driving factor, and instead, we're experiencing "risk on" periods driven by broader external variables.

1. Macro backdrop.

In 2020-2021, we experienced record money printing, with stimulus checks flowing and retail flush with cash.

Now, we're in a monetary tightening environment, meaning there is less liquidity in the economy.

This fundamentally changes how "alt seasons" or periods of "risk on" look.

Before we dig in, we need to address the reason why we haven't experienced a classic "alt season" yet this cycle.

The market dynamics are fundamentally different now, and this is reflected in the final model.

There are 3 major reasons.

Make sure you only buy a coin when you REALLY align with the underlying thesis/trade.

5. Enter new positions carefully.

For most coins, I'd rather wait for a show of strength than try and pick the bottom.

I'm leaning on key HTF technicals to validate momentum/serve as invalidation in case the trend shifts.

See below the only two scenarios I would buy a coin right now.

4. If you're short on stables, park some to the side.

I'm currently ~35% stables and am targeting ~45% by end of month.

This is fairly aggressive compared to some, but I don't feel the need to be fully exposed here.

I've always recommended the average person holds at least 20% of their crypto portfolio in stables. It makes it much easier to deal with volatility, and gives you optionality to capitalise on new opportunities as they arise.

3. Trim positions you were overexposed to pre-dip.

During the liquidation cascade on Sunday night, if there were positions which were causing you to lose sleep, it's a sign you're overexposed and should look at reducing/cutting these positions - at least now many of them have bounced somewhat.

This can be done incrementally if needed (i.e. laddering out on pumps).

And if there are tokens that you believe will outperform in the next leg, but you don't already hold, start developing plan to accumulate these projects (point 5 will touch on this in more depth).

Just make sure your conviction is rooted in a real thesis, and not strictly based on price performance.

2. Consolidate into high conviction positions only.

If there are tokens which you STILL love, even after the correction, it's a good sign that you should consolidate into these positions.

Your aim is to hold assets which will survive turbulence and thrive during the next leg of the bull run.

I want you to do an exercise.

Go through your entire portfolio and evaluate EVERY single position one-by-one.

Ask yourself:
‚Ä¢ Do I still believe in this token?
‚Ä¢ Would I be be ok if this token dropped another 30-40%?
‚Ä¢ If it drops another 30%, would I have the conviction to buy more?

If you answer yes, hold (or follow step 2).

If you answer no, it's probably a sign you should either cut or reduce exposure.

1. Cut the tokens you don't believe in.

This is not the time to hold low-quality projects.

This is a choppy market.

In these conditions, it's easy to get shaken out due to violent swings.

Make it easy on yourself by getting rid of tokens that cause you stress.

If you're feeling completely lost in the crypto market right now, you're not alone.

These are some of the trickiest conditions we've ever had.

But if you don't act quick, your portfolio could keep on bleeding.

Ngl, Satoshi would probably hate how TradFi is taking over the crypto space.

Great for our bags in terms of making money (especially $BTC), not great in terms of the core principles of decentralisation.

The world's biggest fund managers (like BlackRock) are actively incentivised to push the crypto/tokenisation narrative.

Don't underestimate how powerful this is.

They own the ETFs, they want to make money on management fees.

They take fees on their clients, thus are incentivised to earn the biggest margins possible.

How do you do this?

Push as many people into $BTC as possible, as price goes up, you earn more fees. This also causes more retail FOMO which (you guessed it) leads to more fees on the ETF.

Because 99% of people are underexposed to this asset class, there's vast untapped potential.

Equities are fairly saturated at this point, relative to an emerging asset class which has so much upside.

Fink smells the opportunity to be market leaders (that's why he's been pushing tokenisation so hard - literally trillions of dollars in untapped potential).

I like sectors where it's easy to pick winners.

In AI szn last March, it was easy (TAO, RNDR, FET) were all good proxies that responded strongly when AI ran.

In memes, it was easy at first (PEPE & WIF, POPCAT etc.), then it got super saturated.

The same started happening to AI.

Usually this is a result of how easy it is to larp/spin up a project which commands mindshare.

The reason I like RWA/DeFi right now is because it's very hard to larp.

Either you have the licensing or you don't.
Either you have revenue or you don't.
Either you have clients or you don't.
Either you generate fees or you don't.

Much easier to pick the winners in these sectors as there is less to choose from, which increases your odds of hitting a proxy which actually performs.

You need your "beta" plays actually correlate to the underlying sector/narrative itself, or it's a useless trade.

(btw I'm still extremely bullish on AI - observation here is that it's harder to pick winners vs a sector like RWA).

My daily non-negotiables as a full-time crypto investor/content creator:

‚Ä¢ Wake up early (5am)
‚Ä¢ Plan day + scan market + read in sunlight in the morning
‚Ä¢ Complete morning check list (writing, discord, TG)
‚Ä¢ Gym (PPL split + tennis on certain days)
‚Ä¢ Film YT video
‚Ä¢ Get at least 3 high-leverage tasks done each day
‚Ä¢ Only content meetings in morning, all other meetings (BD etc. are in the afternoon only - this way my highest leverage thing *content* is always done to the highest standard & before I get bogged down with other stuff)
‚Ä¢ Hot shower + read before bed (I also sauna but this is optional imo)
‚Ä¢ Go to sleep early (before 9pm)

I never make it through my entire to-do list each day, but the key thing is prioritisation, and making sure the tasks I AM doing are high leverage (can use Google tasks, Todoist, Notion, or even Apple notes for this - as long as you're tracking).

Other pro tip (which I'm only starting to utilise more) is delegation. Most mundane tasks can be outsourced to allow me to focus primarily on doing what I do best (researching, writing, thinking).

Imo best combo is building a cash-flow business + investing.

Most people aren't cut out for active trading.

Better to focus energy on finding ways to increase your income/reinvest back into your core business/yourself.

Financial freedom is paradoxical.

The things you need to do to achieve freedom often result in being less free..

Scaling a company? Now you're responsible for the livelihoods of dozens of employees.

Make millions? Now you're responsible for protecting it in a world where many people are trying to take advantage of you.

Yes, you undoubtedly solve the basic problems (like bills/rent/food), etc.

But, it comes with a new set of problems, which end up feeling relatively similar (in terms of stress) to the old ones.

But, ultimately, I believe life is more about purpose than it is ultimate "freedom"..

The feeling of waking up with a purpose/mission trumps that of boredom/relaxation.

And purpose isn't just business, purpose can be be family, relationships, up-skilling a hobby.. As long as there's a powerful force that pushes you forward every day.

But as long as something is at stake, you'll never be "free"..

The launch of Pump Fun is directly correlated to the destruction of the altcoin market vs $BTC. üëá

The reason we've seen no major "alt season" across majors, is because the speculative capital that would've once poured into top 200 assets, instead decided to jump the gun and flood into on-chain low caps instead.

The early birds & insiders got insanely rich from this. And truthfully, there was a lot of money to be made (and still is - it isn't going away). But most retail (who entered late) lost, as is the case in most altcoin cycles.

But unlike 2022, where their losses were limited mostly to CEX alts with solid liquidity, instead, they got stuck into illiquid on-chain memes which quickly retraced -70-80%.

Thus, it became a wealth destruction event much greater than the early 2022 bear (LUNA aside), even though BTC (and some majors) are still in a macro bull trend.

Understanding this, it's clear to see why sentiment is so poor.

Pump Fun fundamentally changed the game, arguably for the worse. But it has also made crypto the biggest casino on the planet, which is a powerful onboarding tool.

Btw, I don't "blame" Pump Fun, as its launch is in direct response to the brash crypto regulation which has made it impossible to fair-launch projects. The SEC essentially forced the industry to find ways to make the industry "fairer", as opposed to the VC/insider-fuelled bull run of 2021.

Since 2017, we haven't found a reasonable system to make the space more equitable in terms of the way projects launch (airdrops being the outlier and probably the best model i.e. $HYPE and $JUP). But maybe that will change under Trump.

There are 2 times when you want to buy coins in this environment. 

1. Major liquidation events like yesterday (best R/R).

2. On a confirmed reversal for specific alts, with clear HTF invalidation.

Other than that, be patient, don't buy dead-cat bounces or slow bleed.

When you see a new trend establishing, go aggressive early, and get more defensive as the trend matures. 

This applies to both larger cycles and mini cycles.

The earlier you are to adapt to new conditions, the better your R/R on those entries.

Crypto rewards speed and punishes complacency.

Crypto content creator perspective on why "retail" is so frustrating sometimes.

I made 300+ videos in the bear market (from 2022-2023), I went from 50k views/vid to 10k views/vid at one point.

No one gave a sh*t.

There were some absolutely outrageous entries in some of these videos (like $SOL  at $12, $ETH at $1,100, even $PEPE before it did a 100x). 

Then, the market pumped up only for 6 months in 2023-2024, and views only skyrocketed to 80k/day during the LAST 10% of the move.

Then people complain how they got rekt, even tho they couldn't care less for months prior (I always preach risk management but people don't listen - they just see coin and ape).

It's why being a content creator is so difficult in this space. 

You could have 20 great "calls", but the 21st could be the one that loses money. 

And naturally, since views are always skewed towards the end of a run, not the start - the % of people that lose money is higher than the actual % strike rate.

And actually trading this market has nothing to do with *always* being profitable, what matters is that you're profitable *overall*.

Even a 51% strike rate can make you stupidly rich if your position sizing is correct.

Catch 22 (no real alpha in this post just pointing out a clear flaw which applies to basically every market - a.k.a. being early makes you money, being late doesn't).

The unfortunate thing for altcoins, is that this news-driven market is super discouraging for investors.

Trader's paradise for sure - but most retail just buys and holds. 

This volatility is too much for them to handle mentally.

So they leave.

And the altcoin spot bid leaves with them.

This is a classic sign that the market is leaning bearish (lights off mode) currently.

How the market reacts to news tells you all you need to know about sentiment.

Bull trend: Market shrugs off bad news, and pumps on good news 

Bear trend: Market shrugs off good news, dumps on bad news

But these trends can sometimes just be multi-week/multi-month. That's why it's important to absorb early signs of a trend shift, and the market's reaction to news is a simple way to do this (not foolproof, but a symptom of an underlying issue/bias).

"Trader's paradise, investors hell" rings  more true now than ever.

If you're investing, make sure you're only holding quality that won't have you panicking every -20%/+20% move.

If you're trading, there are many opportunities - just make sure your risk management is on point.

Honestly, if you hold on-chain alts - in a way this crash is worse than the early bear market of 2022. So it's no wonder that the vibes are so terrible rn, despite $BTC sitting ~$100k.

Last cycle, most people just held CEX alts. There were A LOT less of them than we have now, and alts on major CEXs have much more liquidity than their on-chain counterparts.

Low liquidity means moves are reflexively violent both to the upside and the downside. That's why you're seeing so many "Burj Khalifa" style charts rn. Alts pump much harder when conditions are favourable, but also drop much harder and faster when things turn.

Thus, it's really been a traders market. There have been insane gains if you've been able to catch rotations early (like memes and AI agents), but it's hard to hold many altcoins with confidence for the "long-term" with dispersion/attention deficit at its ATH (especially if it's on chain).

Best to adapt a mental model which allows you to capitalise on risk-on periods, and protect yourself during risk-off periods, instead of relying on a broader "alt season" to save you.

"Lights off" mode (right now): Cut losers fast, long slow.

"Lights on" mode: Let your winners ride, long fast.

Knowing which environment we're in is key - and the quicker you adapt the better.

10. Don't be complacent

Complacency is the silent killer in crypto.

If you have an opportunity to secure profits on a pump, do it.
If you have an opportunity to de-risk a position fast, do it.

Speed and attentiveness matter a lot in a space as adaptive as crypto.

9. Hold a maximum of 5-10 core positions (the less the better)

Holding too many coins has a bunch of unwanted side effects:

‚Ä¢ Becomes impossible to manage invalidations/TPing
‚Ä¢ Can't keep track of news/updates which may affect fundamentals
‚Ä¢ Can't re-evaluate your thesis as often

The less coins you hold in your core portfolio, the better. You can still trade new coins based on technicals and new trends which arise, but you're not married to them.

The president of the United States signed an executive order to establish a Strategic Bitcoin Reserve. This is HUGE!

Here are the key takeaways from the executive order. üëá

‚Ä¢ There will be two distinct reserves: a Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and a Digital Asset Stockpile.

‚Ä¢ The Strategic Bitcoin Reserve will be capitalized using $BTC that has been seized by the US government.

‚Ä¢ The United States is committed to not selling any $BTC within the Strategic Reserve, subject to certain exemptions.

‚Ä¢ No new $BTC will be purchased using taxpayer money, however there may be budget-neutral strategies to acquire more $BTC.

‚Ä¢ The Digital Asset Stockpile will consist of digital assets other than $BTC that has also been seized by the US government.

‚Ä¢ Unlike the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve, the government will not be acquiring any additional cryptocurrencies for the Digital Asset Stockpile.

8. Manage your position sizing in accordance with the risk of a coin

My blanket rule is I never put 5% of my portfolio into a single position, unless I have extreme conviction.

Your allocated weighting should be in accordance with the risk profile of a coin.

Higher risk coin = smaller weighting
Lower risk coin = larger weighting

7. Don't rush decisions

Make money slowly.
Protect money quickly.

I still return to this quote often. https://t.co/4et16vlwE6

6. Let your winners ride, cut your losers fast

Most people in crypto tend to do the opposite, because selling your losers feels bad.

But most of the time, you'll make a lot more money giving your winners space to ride (whilst TPing incrementally, of course), and cutting losers swiftly.

5. Set alerts

This is such low hanging fruit, but is something barely anyone seems to do.

Set HTF alerts on TradingView for your major holds/trades.

This way you will always know when something is approaching your de-risk (or TP) level.

4. ALWAYS have a technical validation AND invalidation for a trade

Fundamentals may change over time, but technicals are black and white.

By having pre-determined parameters (i.e. "if $SOL closes below x level for 2 consecutive days I will cut 50% of my position") you will save yourself a lot of pain.

You can always get back in on confirmation of a resumed uptrend.

I use a combination of HTF S/R levels + moving averages to form the basis of my setups - but there is nuance to how you execute, of course.

3. Define your trading vs holding split

Right now I'm sitting around 50/50.

50% allocated to high conviction positions (with partial invalidations), and 50% for trading (this sits in stables + a mix of short-mid term positions).

Your %s will depend on a) how much time you have, and b) your skillset/edge in the market.

2. Build REAL conviction in a thesis before buying

If you find yourself less bullish on an altcoin because price went down - it's a sign you didn't build true conviction in the first place.

Tbh - there aren't that many high quality assets in crypto anyway.

For the rest, trade.

1. Know when to be risk on, and risk off

Never force a position.

During "lights off" mode your #1 priority is to survive.

During "lights on" mode, your #1 priority is to capitalise (and make as much profit as possible).
